body_html:
Here is an example video. It explains that CUDA 9.1 is not compatible in Windows, yet it advice to use pip, when my system has pip3
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uIm3DMprk7M&t=12s

The instructions here
https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_windows

Do not explain that newer versions should not be used. It is logical to assume that the webpage is outdated, so the user installs 9.1, because nvidia redirects the users to the download page of 9.1

I followed a mix of instructions, so I managed to run this code on a command line

import tensorflow as tf
hello = tf.constant('Hello, TensorFlow!')
sess = tf.Session()
print(sess.run(hello))

but it still doesn't works on Visual Studio 2017, and there is not a tool to diagnose what is going wrong.

The instructions need to be actually tested, updated, maintained and clearly written from an official source.

The present state is a mess.

but it still doesn't works on Visual Studio 2017, and there is not a tool to diagnose what is going wrong.

body:
Here is an example video. It explains that CUDA 9.1 is not compatible in Windows, yet it advice to use pip, when my system has pip3
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uIm3DMprk7M&t=12s

The instructions here
https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_windows

Do not explain that newer versions should not be used. It is logical to assume that the webpage is outdated, so the user installs 9.1, because nvidia redirects the users to the download page of 9.1

I followed a mix of instructions, so I managed to run this code on a command line
>>> import tensorflow as tf
>>> hello = tf.constant('Hello, TensorFlow!')
>>> sess = tf.Session()
>>> print(sess.run(hello))

but it still doesn't works on Visual Studio 2017, and there is not a tool to diagnose what is going wrong.



**The instructions need to be actually tested, updated, maintained and clearly written from an official source.**

The present state is a mess.
